description.narrative: Child Rights Connect (CRC) is the largest network for children’s rights with more than 80 national, regional and international member organizations. The intervention's overall goal is to advance the global movement for children’s human rights for the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and its Optional Protocols. CRC's work is based on three main intervention points: 1. Empowering children’s rights defenders 2. Strengthening the UN human rights system 3. Advancing the global movement for children’s human rights. The contribution is 16 million SEK in core support to CRC over a four-year period (2019-2022), consisting of 4 million SEK annually.

Child Rights Connect (CRC) utgör det största nätverket för barns rättigheter med mer än 80 medlemsorganisationer såväl nationella, regionala och internationella. Insatsen syftar till att främja den globala rörelsen för barns mänskliga rättigheter genom att stärka den universella ratificeringen av barnkonventionen (UN CRC) och tilläggsprotokoll. CRC:s arbete fokuserar på följande områden: 1. Stöd till barnrättsförsvarare och barn som försvarare av mänskliga rättigheter 2. Stärka FN-systemet för mänskliga rättigheter 3. Stärka och samordna den globala rörelsen för barns mänskliga rättigheter. Insatsen uppgår till 16 MSEK i kärnstöd till CRC under en fyra-årsperiod (2019–2022), fördelat på 4 miljoner kronor årligen.

The intervention's overall objective is to advance the global movement for children's human rights for the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and its Optional Protocols. Child Rights Connect does this by convening and engaging with civil society and other relevant actors, by fostering cooperation, and by empowering children’s rights defenders to meaningfully participate in global advocacy for children’s rights. The expected outcomes of the intervention are as follows: 1. Empowered Children's Rights Defenders. Children’s rights defenders, effectively influence and use UN human rights mechanisms with engagement in monitoring, reporting and international advocacy, and apply a child rights-based approach in their advocacy and development work contributing towards the SDGs at national level. 2. Strengthened international human rights mechanisms and standards for children. With children’s rights higher and more broadly integrated on the agenda, the UN human rights mechanisms strengthen children’s rights standards, ensure safe and meaningful participation of children human rights defenders, and better promote and protect children’s human rights. 3. A global movement on children’s human rights. Increased involvement of a wider range of key stakeholders for their effective contribution towards the realisation of children’s human rights. 4. A well-functioning Network. The Child Rights Connect Network has a more balanced regional outreach and is energised, with members actively engaged to take action towards the realisation of child rights at international, national and local levels. 5. An effective and efficient organisation. Child Rights Connect is a well-functioning global organisation with effective, efficient and sustainable governance and management.

description.narrative:
Four key achievements:
The below case studies highlight progress and remaining challenges in contributing to CRCncts outcomes.
A first comprehensive guidance on the implementation of the rights of child human rights defenders (related primarily to Outcome 1) was produced. Based on CRCncts initiativ, the Day of General Discussion (DGD) of the CRC Committee on Protecting and empowering children as human rights defenders was the start to highlight some of the barriers to the realization of the rights of children who act as human rights defenders (CHRDs). One of the most fundamental problem is that there is little understanding of who CHRDs are, why it is important to recognize them, and what is distinct about their role, status, and rights as opposed to adult defenders.Through a technical workshop with children and experts, CRCnct developed a roadmap for implementation of the DGD Outcome Document recommendations which includes individual commitments and concrete actions that are key to making the DGD recommendations a reality for CHRDs. Interpreting the articles of the UN Declaration on human rights defenders from a child rights perspective and developed in partnership with Queens University of Belfast following a process of consultations with children, CRCnct members, and national, regional and global experts, including the UN Special Rapporteur on the situation of HRDs (SR HRDs) and CRC Committee members CRCncts 2020 publication, The Rights of Child Human Rights Defenders: Implementation Guide, lays the foundation for the protection and promotion of CHRDs and identifies some of the gaps to be further addressed at all levels. This resource is important to build awareness and legal understanding of what it means to be a CHRD and how their rights must be respected, protected, and fulfilled at the national level. Feedback from both children and experts demonstrates how the Guide can be in advancing the rights, empowerment, and protection of CHRDs.
Progress made towards recognizing and advancing childrens right to a healthy environment (related primarily to Outcomes 1 and 3). The consideration of child rights is key for de sustainable development and relevant to environmental or climate-related policies, laws, and action. 2020 was an important year for making the healthy environment a child rights concern. It started with the extraordinary session of the CRC Committee in Samoa in March 2020, where CRCnct supported child environmental HRDs from the Pacific to share their views and recommendations with the Committee. It then continued with the UN Human Rights Council (HRC) holding the annual full day meeting on the rights of the child on the theme of Realizing the rights of the child through a healthy environment. For the first time ever, two children environmental human rights defenders (supported by CRCnct and members) spoke up in both panels to denounce environmental issues affecting childrens rights, while the UN High Commissioner for human rights openly stated that the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbates the effects of environmental harms on childrens rights. Thanks to Child Rights Connect, I received an effective support throughout this process, despite the distance. My participation allowed me to speak freely. It helped me to see that adults and authorities are interested in childrens right, Junior, child environmental human rights defender from Ivory Coast. The ambition was to address the climate change crisis through adopting, by consensus, the annual resolution on the rights of the child with a focus on realizing the rights of the child through a healthy environment on 7 October 2020. The resolution clearly states that the environmental crisis is a children's rights crisis, and that States should take all measures to protect children's rights from environmental harm. It largely reflects the advocacy efforts undertaken throughout the year by CRCnct, together with its Working Group on child rights and the environment coordinated by Terre des Homme and the Child Rights International Network (CRIN), as well as key partners such as UNICEF and UNEP.
The rights, protection, and empowerment of CHRDs advanced through childrens influence on the General Comment No.25 of the CRC Committee, channelled by CRCnct (related primarily to Outcomes 1, 2 and 3). Although the CRC Committee adopted its General Comment outside of the reporting period, the case study is included in this report as it is the result of CRCncts multi-year, sustained engagement, including in 2020. In March 2021, the CRC Committee officially launched its new General Comment No. 25 on childrens rights in relation to the digital environment. This is the first authoritative legal document which recognises explicitly that childrens rights apply both offline and online. It is also significant in that it considers the full spectrum of childrens rights against the full range of the impacts of digital technology. Through CRCnct, children, in particular CHRDs, played a key role in influencing the scope of the General Comment, as well as its drafting process and the final text. Findings from the online consultation with more than 2,695 children in the context informed the joint submission made by CRCnct and its members together in March 2019 on the concept note of the General Comment. It encouraged the CRC Committee, in framing its General Comment to recognize that the digital environment provides CHRDs both additional opportunities and challenges that are distinctive to them.
Bridging the information gap between UN human rights mechanisms and civil society during the pandemic (related primarily to Outcomes 2, 3 and 5) CRCnct continued to play a important role in bridging the communication gap between civil society from around the world and the CRC Committee as well as other UN mechanisms, even more so in the context of the pandemic. This action was as important as enabling childrens rights defenders engagement in the CRC reporting cycle, as highlighted by a Luxembourg CSO representative, when discussing the value of CRCncts work: "Before the dates were not published, and it was difficult to follow when the deadlines were." This role became even more crucial during the pandemic as the work of the UN mechanisms was significantly disrupted, rescheduled, and shifted online with very little public information available and advance notification. CRCnct has become even more the key reference point for civil society, including children, and the main source of upto- date information on possibilities of engagement with the CRC Committee and other UN human rights mechanisms through a dedicated webpage11 and targeted technical assistance to CSOs. The process of information-sharing went both ways, as CRCnct used its strategic partnership with the CRC Committee to feed back views, perspectives, and ideas of civil society from around the globe to the Committee
Source: These results have been collected from the 2020 Annual Reporting from CRCnct. For additional information on results see dox:016986/21
